current_fact.fact_text: On January 20, 1726, Johann Sebastian Bach premiered his church cantata "Meine Seufzer, meine Tränen" (My sighs, my tears), BWV 13, in Leipzig. Scored for a modest ensemble, it weaves haunting melodies and dissonances to depict spiritual grief turning slowly toward hope.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

current_fact.match_reason: A meditative, introspective Bach cantata about sighs and tears pairs with the slow, reflective mood of “Slow Planet,” both turning quiet emotion into spacious sound.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1788, the main body of Britain’s First Fleet arrived at Botany Bay, beginning the colonization of Australia. Unsatisfied with the shallow, exposed anchorage, Governor Arthur Phillip scouted further north and chose the deeper, more sheltered Port Jackson—today home to Sydney Harbour.

episode.title: Morning Drops #38 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

queue.match_reason: The First Fleet’s search for a safer harbour mirrors the episode’s theme of travel, new places, and quietly changing course to find ‘the place’ that fits.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1783, Great Britain and France agreed on preliminary peace articles that paved the way for the Treaty of Paris and the formal end of the American Revolutionary War. After years of global conflict, empires shifted from cannon fire to careful negotiation across the table.

episode.title: Morning Drops #21 - Endless Summer
episode.description: Recorded from Fano, a quiet town on the Adriatic coast where summer stretches long and slow. Between swims, simple meals, and time with family, Gaia reflects on the kind of music that helps us return to ourselves. Through different shades of jazz — from minimal and meditative to warm and rhythmic — an invitation to slip into that endless summer feeling.

queue.match_reason: A hard‑won peace after war evokes the calm exhale after a storm; the episode’s warm, summery jazz feels like a long-awaited season of quiet after years of conflict.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1567, at the Battle of Rio de Janeiro, Portuguese forces under Estácio de Sá drove the French out of Guanabara Bay. The clash decided which European power would control the spectacular natural harbour that later cradled the city of Rio de Janeiro.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

queue.match_reason: A naval battle over one of Earth’s great bays connects naturally to an episode recorded at sea, with songs about waves, sun, and the stories carried on the water.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1841, Britain occupied Hong Kong Island during the First Opium War, transforming a sparsely populated island of fishing villages into a strategic colonial port. Over time, it grew into one of the world’s densest urban skylines—a crossroads of commerce, culture, and contested sovereignty.

episode.title: Morning Drops #17 - Steel City
episode.description: Gaia takes us on a short trip through Sheffield's sounds — from electronic textures to raw guitars and sharp storytelling. Four tracks, one city, different edges of the same story.
songs: The Human League - The Sound Of The Crowd

queue.match_reason: Hong Kong’s evolution into a dense, industrial-tinged metropolis resonates with an episode about Sheffield’s urban sound—both cities telling their stories through concrete, steel, and music.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1839, Chilean forces won the Battle of Yungay in the Peruvian Andes, toppling the Peru–Bolivian Confederation. The victory reshaped the political map of western South America and is still commemorated in Chile as a symbol of national resilience.

episode.title: Morning Drops #22 - Sicilians On The Dolomites
episode.description: Hosted by Yasmin, a musical journey inspired by the mountains. Joined by two special guests, exploring the tracks they've chosen, hearing the stories behind their picks, and discovering the personal memories each song brings to life — a blend of music, voices, and landscapes you can hear.
songs: Florian Pellissier Quintet - Coup de foudre à Thessalonique
Lucio Dalla & Francesco De Gregori - Ma come fanno i marinai

queue.match_reason: A decisive Andean mountain battle pairs with an episode devoted to music and memory in the mountains, both set against dramatic highland landscapes that shape human stories.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1954, the National Negro Network launched in the United States, linking 40 radio stations into one of the first major broadcast platforms dedicated to Black audiences. It carried dramas, variety shows, and commentary that challenged a segregated media landscape.

episode.title: Morning Drops #34 - Soul Sisters
episode.description: A tribute to four iconic voices — women who have shaped the way we listen, feel, and move. Each track carries a different kind of presence: one that holds you, one that questions, one that grounds, and one that lets go. An energy that is soulful, raw, and unapologetically feminine.
songs: Grace Jones - Walking in the Rain
Aretha Franklin - A Rose Is Still a Rose

queue.match_reason: A pioneering Black radio network aligns with an episode celebrating powerful female voices and representation in music—both expand who gets heard on the airwaves.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1921, the British K-class submarine HMS K5 sank mysteriously during a training exercise in the English Channel, killing all 56 crew. Designed for unusual high speeds with steam turbines, the K‑class earned a grim reputation and the nickname "Kalamity" class.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

queue.match_reason: A tragic submarine loss in deep water parallels an episode built around diving and immersion; the playlist offers a gentler, healing dive where the sea becomes reflection rather than disaster.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1942, senior Nazi officials met at the Wannsee Conference in a Berlin suburb to coordinate the "Final Solution"—the systematic murder of Europe’s Jews. The meeting turned genocidal ideology into chilling bureaucratic planning.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

queue.match_reason: This dark moment of dehumanizing categorization is countered by an episode about resisting labels and asserting humanity—Kendrick Lamar’s conscious rap becomes a modern answer to bureaucratic hatred.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1990, Soviet troops cracked down on pro-independence demonstrations in Baku, Azerbaijan—a night remembered as Black January. The brutal assault, which killed scores of civilians, also galvanized the Azerbaijani independence movement.

episode.title: Morning Drops #23 - Morning Dubs
episode.description: Recorded while still processing Houghton Festival. One of the mornings there, waking up in the woods to a reggae DJ set — no phone signal, just trees, music, and loved ones. A slow selection of reggae, dub, and morning rhythms. Dubs instead of drops. Start your day slow — with space to breathe.
songs: The Gaylads - Joy in the Morning
King Tubby - King Tubby Meets the Rockers Uptown

queue.match_reason: Reggae and dub have long critiqued ‘Babylon’—systems of oppression; this episode’s rootsy resistance vibes echo the struggle against Soviet violence remembered in Black January.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1991, Sudan’s government imposed Islamic law (sharia) across the entire country, deepening divisions between the largely Muslim north and the predominantly Christian and animist south. The move intensified the already-raging civil war that would eventually lead to South Sudan’s independence.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

queue.match_reason: Both the Sudanese conflict and Tuareg music emerge from Saharan and Sahelian struggles over land, identity, and faith; desert blues of exile and resistance mirrors the human cost of imposed law and civil war.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1972, Pakistan formally launched its nuclear weapons program, just weeks after losing East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) in the 1971 war. In a meeting famously framed as a choice between "eating grass" or achieving a bomb, the country committed to a clandestine nuclear path.

episode.title: Morning Drops #45 - It Can't Rain Forever
episode.description:
In this first broadcast of 2026, Gaia returns from the vivid landscapes of Morocco to open a space for reflection. This episode navigates the delicate transition between closing a significant chapter and stepping into the new year. It explores the concept of constancy amidst change, celebrating the grounding force of friendship and the creative sanctuary that is Sedna FM.

The musical selection mirrors this journey, moving from the orchestral depth of changing seasons into the golden warmth of psychedelic soul. It recalls memories of Swiss mountains and unexpected downpours, reminding us that shared optimism can weather any storm.

Take a moment to breathe in the new morning and listen deeply.

Mood: Reflective, Warm, Transitional, Hopeful
Music genre: Classic Rock, Psychedelic Soul, Pop Rock, Soft Rock

queue.match_reason: The turn toward nuclear weapons after a national trauma is a stormy chapter; this reflective, hopeful episode—with its rain motifs and encouragement not to stop—offers a contemplative counterpoint about moving through dark transitions.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2018, Turkey began Operation Olive Branch, shelling and later invading the Afrin region of Syria to push back Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces. The offensive added yet another layer to the already complex Syrian civil war, displacing tens of thousands of civilians.

episode.title: Morning Drops #13 - Demystifying Reggaeton
episode.description: Yasmin takes us on a journey through the real story of reggaeton — from its roots in Panama and Puerto Rico to its global evolution. Exploring the genre's history, influences, and cultural impact.
songs: Renato - Chica de los Ojos Café
B. F. Yaviah - Si Tu Quieres Fumar

queue.match_reason: A modern, messy conflict invites contemporary, politically-aware urban sounds; this episode dissects a globalized genre born from marginalized voices, echoing how culture and power collide far beyond the battlefield.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2018, gunmen stormed Kabul’s Inter-Continental Hotel, sparking a 12‑hour siege that left around 40 people dead. The attack turned a symbol of international connection and hospitality into a deadly battleground.

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back
episode.description:
In this first Morning Drop of 2026, Yasmin opens a space for quiet reflection on the nature of transitions. The episode traces a personal journey that began three years ago, when a sudden injury on New Year’s Day turned a desire for movement into a mandatory season of stillness.

Through the story of a broken knee and the slow process of relearning to walk, the narrative explores the difference between being strong and being aware. It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

Mood: Reflective, Resilient, Grounded
Music genre: Indie Pop, Cinematic, World, Soul

We invite you to listen deeply and find comfort in your own pace.
songs: Kelly Finnigan - I Don't Wanna Wait
Goran Bregović & Iggy Pop - This Is a Film

queue.match_reason: A brutal, drawn-out hotel siege asks for a space of aftermath and healing; this reflective episode about recovering from trauma and learning to accept help offers a human-scale lens on endurance.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2009, Barack Obama was inaugurated as the 44th U.S. president, becoming the country’s first African-American leader. More than a million people braved the Washington cold to witness a milestone that echoed centuries of struggle and imagination.

episode.title: Morning Drops #04 - Bars With Balls
episode.description: Yasmin dives into Women's Day through the voices of four incredible female rappers. Morning fire from the magic planet of Sedna FM — move your hands up and down with us. Hip hop culture through a feminine lens.
songs: Little Simz - Point and Kill (feat. Obongjayar)

queue.match_reason: Obama’s inauguration is tied to Black cultural power and representation; an episode spotlighting women in hip‑hop underscores how voices from the margins reach the centre of political and cultural life.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1953, Dwight D. Eisenhower took office as the 34th U.S. president, the first to be inaugurated on January 20 under the newly effective Twentieth Amendment. The constitutional shift shortened the traditional post-election "lame duck" period, bringing leadership changes closer to the vote.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

queue.match_reason: A constitutional change that reshaped political timing feels like a structural 'classic'; this first Morning Drops, filled with timeless tracks, mirrors the sense of a new but lasting tradition beginning.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2017, Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th president of the United States, bringing a media-saturated, reality‑TV persona into the country’s highest office. His inauguration marked a sharp rhetorical and stylistic break from his predecessors.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.match_reason: A presidency deeply entangled with spectacle, social media, and constant connectivity pairs with an episode questioning our digital addictions and how screens shape politics and perception.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2025, Donald Trump was inaugurated again as the 47th U.S. president, becoming—at that moment—the oldest person ever to take the oath of office. The non-consecutive return echoed earlier eras yet unfolded in an age of instant global commentary.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.match_reason: A rare non-consecutive presidency invites reflection on repetition, cycles, and what (if anything) is learned between terms; this episode frames change and return through the lens of growth and slow understanding.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1973, Amílcar Cabral—an agronomist turned revolutionary who led the independence movements of Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde—was assassinated in Conakry, Guinea. His blend of poetry, political theory, and guerrilla struggle made him one of Africa’s most influential anti-colonial thinkers.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

queue.match_reason: Cabral’s anti-colonial struggle and political thought resonate with Afrobeat’s fiercely political roots; the episode’s focus on African musical resistance makes it a natural echo of his legacy.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 1990, massive protests swept Azerbaijan as part of the Soviet Union’s dissolution, with demonstrators demanding independence and protesting ethnic violence. The unrest and subsequent crackdown became a key chapter in the unraveling of Soviet authority in the Caucasus.

episode.title: Morning Drops #20 - Hitchhiking Poland
episode.description: Yasmin takes you back to the summer of 2020, when borders were still uncertain and a long-held wish to visit Poland finally came true. Through four tracks, tracing her journey from a stranger's couch in Poznań to the peaks of Zakopane.

queue.match_reason: Protests during the Soviet collapse in the Caucasus resonate with an episode roaming a post‑Soviet landscape via Polish and Russian sounds, both tracing how borders and identities shift across Eastern Europe.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2009, while Barack Obama took the oath in Washington, a very different crowd was gathering in Reykjavík: Icelanders protesting outside parliament as anger over the 2008 financial collapse boiled into the so‑called Pots and Pans Revolution. Their banging cookware became a soundtrack for demanding accountability from bankers and politicians.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

queue.match_reason: A noisy, cathartic street uprising against economic injustice fits the raw, energetic, protest‑leaning mix of Sedna’s very first episode, featuring voices like Nas, Canserbero, and Fela Kuti.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2018, Turkey’s government announced the Afrin offensive under the name Operation Olive Branch—an ironically peaceful label for a cross-border operation involving artillery, airstrikes, and ground troops. The campaign highlighted how modern wars are waged with both weapons and carefully crafted narratives.

episode.title: Morning Drops #44 - Residente
episode.description:
In this edition of Morning Drops, Yasmin navigates the complex geography of René Pérez Joglar, known to the world as Residente. His story is not just a musical evolution; it is a timeline marked by resistance, lyrical obsession, and a relentless search for identity.

From the gated streets of Trujillo Alto to the global stage, we explore how a restless mind transformed into the voice of a generation. The selection moves through the textures of his life: hearing the raw energy of his early rebellion, the sharp precision of his political critique, and finally, the fragile silence of his most personal confessions.

It is a study in duality. We witness the rapper who dismantles giants and the son who misses his mother. It is a soundscape that proves that sometimes, the loudest revolution happens inside.

Mood: Raw, Revolutionary, Introspective, Honest
Music genre: Latin Alternative, Hip Hop, Urban, World

queue.match_reason: The contrast between the operation’s benign name and violent reality matches Residente’s sharp political critique and focus on stripping away euphemisms to expose power and conflict.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2017, as Trump’s motorcade rolled through Washington, hundreds of thousands worldwide joined Women’s Marches the following day, turning streets into seas of pink hats and handmade signs. The juxtaposition highlighted how inaugurations can spark both celebration and organized dissent.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Women of Rock
episode.description: A tribute to the women who shaped the sound of rock, the ones who picked up a guitar and refused to ask for permission. The conversation unfolds in Italian, led by Gaia and her father. A dialogue between generations and a reminder that the pulse of rock has always belonged to anyone brave enough to play it loud. Distortion, rhythm, freedom.
songs: Joan Jett & The Blackhearts - I Love Rock 'n Roll

queue.match_reason: The surge of women-led protest energy that framed this inauguration day belongs sonically with an episode celebrating women who refused to ask permission, turning guitars into megaphones.

queue.fact_text: On January 20, 2018, while war raged elsewhere on the news, Syrian skies carried migrating birds over ancient olive groves and devastated towns alike. Even on days of conflict and politics, nature continues its quiet cycles above us.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

queue.match_reason: Ending the day with nature’s quiet continuity, this Arctic orca journey mirrors the idea that even amid human conflict, the non-human world moves in its own vast, patient rhythms.
